[22]. There can be strategic mitigation and tactical mitigations, as depicted in Figure 3-6. 3-6. SORA Air-Conflict Mitigation Process Assignment of SAIL from Air Collision Risk: Using a look up table, the Air-SAIL is 4.
mapped directly from the final (i.e., mitigated) ARC level, as indicated in Table 3-2. xvi
 Table 3-3. Air-SAIL Values Based on Assessed Air Risk Class Final ARC Air-SAIL
ARC 4 SAIL VI
ARC 3 SAIL IV
ARC 2 SAIL II
ARC 1 SAIL I Determination of Uncontained Integrity Level: Depending on the ARC level, further 5.
assessment is made on based on the intended proximity to adjacent airspaces with higher 
AEC levels. Uncontained integrity levels needed for the phases of flight or flight 
segments that are adjacent to sensitive/restricted airspaces [22]. The definition of 
adjacent is subjective.
Tactical Mitigation Performance Requirement (TMPR) and Robustness Levels: 6.
These indicates the level of the aircrafts ability to avoid collisions with obstacles (See 
and avoid capabilities) and to avoid conflicts with other aircraft (conflict detection 
capabilities). Flights operating with visual line of sight do not need to meet TMPR 
robustness levels; whereas BVLOS operations need to meet the TMPR and robustness 
levels [22]. The TMPR and robustness levels are used as the basis of requirements of the 
operator to meet for approval. The SORA guidance provides Annexes that give more specific information for each of these 
steps for determining the AIR-SAIL. Refer to ANNEX G, the Air Risk Model, for more detailed 
information. 4 i
 Conclusions and Recommendations5
In summary, quantitative risk modeling methods require all model components to be numerically 
quantified and their output to be a numerical value which reflects a physical quantity. In contrast, 
qualitative models allow both quantitative and qualitative inputs. Risk may be calculated by a 
combination of methods, including numerical equations, inference rules (if-then), lookup tables 
(SMS matrices), and many other methods [23]. The principal differences are the explicit 
algorithm of a quantitative probabilistic model versus the flexibility and broader subjective inputs 
and qualitative output of a qualitative model. Model precision is based on the completeness and 
comprehensiveness of the input variables, as well as the quality, timeliness, and utility of the data 
that is used for the inputs. 
Based on the evaluation that follows, it is recommended that the FAA: Come to agreement on standardized safety thresholds and acceptable levels of risk to 1.
guide sUAS risk assessments.
Use a holistic review process such as the SORA (once finalized) or the FAA SMS 2.
assessment processes for those operations in the higher risk categories and/or with a 
required need for increased oversight.
Invest in the development of semi-automated functions when the SORA methodology is 3.
finalized and standardize the wide variety of inputs and integration of standardized safety 
thresholds. 
Consider using the sAAT model to identify the operations with the lowest risk. These 4.
operations could be approved without further analysis. This may help streamline the 
approval process by reducing the number of applications that need more rigorous 
evaluation. 
Consider using the sAAT risk model to explore thresholds for acceptable levels of safety 5.
by examining the most sensitive parameters. Perform research to refine model parameter 
values and integrate and expand industry operational data. i
 References/Bibliography6
[1] T. Aven, "Risk Assessment and Risk Management: Review of Recent Advances on Their Foundation," European Journal of Operational Research, vol. 253, no. 1, pp. 1-13, 2016. 
[2] M. Rausand, Risk Assessment: Theory, Methods, and Applications, John Wiley & Sons, 2011. 
[3] R. E. Barlow et al., "Reliability and Fault Tree Analysis: Theoretical and Applied Aspects of System Reliability and Safety Assessment: Papers," in Society for Industrial and Applied 
Mathematics, Berkeley, 1975. [4] R. Farret et al., "Design of Fault Trees as a Practical Method for Risk Analsysi of CCS: 
Application to the Different Life Stages of Deep Aquifer Storage, Combining Long-Term 
and Short-Term Issues," Energy Procedia, vol. 4, pp. 4193-4198, 2011. [5] R. Melnyk et al., "A Third-Party Casualty Risk Model for Unmanned Aircraft System 
Operations," Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 124, pp. 105-116, 2014. [6] FAA, Order 8040.4B Safety Risk Management Policy, Effective date 02 May 2017. 
[7] M. Hadjimichael, "A Fuzzy Expert System for Aviation Risk Assessment," Expert Systems with Applications, vol. 36, no. 3, pp. 6512-6519, 2009. 
[8] T. Bedford and R. Cooke, Probablistic Risk Analysis: Foundations and Methods, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001. 
[9] A. McNeil, R. Frey and P. Embrechts, Quantitative Risk Management: Concepts, Techniques and Tools Revised Edition, Princeton and Oxford: Princeton University Press, 
2015. [10] Joint Authorities for Rulemaking of Unmanned Systems, JARUS guidelines on Specific 
Operations Risk Assessment, 1.0 ed., 2017. [11] J. Breunig et al., "Modeling Risk-Based Approach for Small Unmanned Aircraft Systems," 
in AIAA Aviation Forum, Atlanta, 2018. [12] R. Aalmoes et al., "A conceptual third party risk model for personal an unmanned aerial 
vehicles," in International Conference on Unmanned Aircraft Systems, Denver, 2015. [13] Range Commanders Council, "Common Risk Criteria for National Test Ranges: Inert 
Debris," 2000. [14] Range Commanders Council, "Range Safety Criteria for Unmanned Air Vehicles," 2001.
[15] P. W. Janser et al., "Lethality of Unprotected Persons due to Debris and Fragments," 1982.
[16] N. Fenlason, "Modified Endoh Method for Calculating Airborne Unmitigated Collision Rates," The MITRE Corporation, McLean, 2017.
[17] J. Moore, "Guessing When Your Drone Will Die," AOPA, 5 March 2018. 
[18] R. Weibel and R. J. Hansman, "Safety Considerations for Operation of Different Classes of UAVs in the NAS," in AIAA 3rd "Unmanned Unlimited" Technical Conference, Workshop 
and Exhibit, 2004. [19] E. T. Compolettano et al., "Ranges of Injury Risk Associated with Impact from Unmanned 
Aircraft Systems," Annals of Biomedical Engineering, vol. 45, no. 12, pp. 2733-2741, 2017. [20] D. Arterburn et al., "FAA UAS Center of Excellence Task AF: UAS Ground Collision 
Severity Evaluation Revision 2," 2017. [21] W. Ryan, "Industry Based Compliance Challenges," in FAA UAS Symposium, Baltimore, 
2018. [22] Joint Authorities for Rulemaking of Unmanned Systems, JARUS guidelines on Specific ii
 Operations Risk Assessment, 1.1 Draft ed., 2018. 
[23] J. Condor et al, "A Comparative Analysis of Risk Assessment Methodologies fo rthe Geologic Storage of Carbon Dioxide," Energy Procedia, vol. 4, pp. 4036-4043, 2011.
